reasoning: The critique targets a specific step in the paper’s case against “easygoing” views: the claim that low-bounded, difference-making, jointly aggregating bounded views are implausible because of scale-tipping. If that dismissal failed, the paper would lose one of its main reasons for thinking the only easygoing slice is unattractive—so it’s somewhat central, though not decisive given the paper’s many other routes to ‘fussiness’ (fragility arguments; linear/unbounded arguments; other bounded-view arguments). However, the critique is mostly a speculative loophole (“maybe the cliff only appears beyond practical scales”) without engaging the paper’s intended cosmological scales (10^22 stars) or the normative nature of the scale-tipping worry (the claim that such sharp regime-changes are implausible even if reachable). So it only weakly undermines the attacked claim. The point is broadly coherent/possible, but underspecified about what ‘reasonable scales’ are and why far larger scales wouldn’t be practically attainable for an advanced civilization.
title: Joint aggregation bounded views may behave well within practically attainable scales
